render.tex: \title{Conditions for differentiability} When is a function $f(x)$ said to be differentiable at $x=a$

reason.tex:
%text A function $f(x)$ is differentiable at $x=a$ if one can \underline\text{unambiguosly} say what the rate of change $f'(x)$ at $x=a$ is So, $f(x)$ must first be continuous at $x=a$. If $f(x)$ is not defined or is otherwise not continuous at $x=a$, then it cannot have a $f'(x)$ at $x=a$
Hence, it cannot have an unambiguous $f'(x)$. Which means it cannot be said to be differentiable But even if it is continous, it is differentiable only if \[ \qquad \lim_{x\to a^-} f'(x) = \lim_{x\to a^+} f'(x) \] For example, $f(x) = \vert x\vert$ is continuous at $x=0$. But for $x < 0, f'(x) = -1$ and for $x > 0, f'(x) = +1$ So, what is the rate of change at $x=0$? Is it $-1$ or $+1$? The question cannot be answered. Hence, $f(x)=\vert x\vert$ is not differentiable at $x=0$%
